subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today, I'd
like to talk about research in backward
causality, and I'm talking about
parapsychology research. This is some of
the most important research in the field
of parapsychology because of its
philosophical and theoretical
implications and also because it has an
implication that you will probably
recognize right away, relates to you. The
first line of studies have been called
presentiment research. The term
presentiment originally, to my
understanding, had to do with the idea
that we often anticipate future events.
If you're anticipating an event, like
if I hold my hands like this right next
to your ears and you know I'm about to
clap my hands like that, you're going to
anticipate perhaps hearing a loud noise.
But in these studies, the
parapsychologists endeavor to rule out
conventional anticipation because they
presented stimuli, typically these were
pictures, actually, as I recall, pictures
that are emotionally charged, both
positive and negative pictures. So, the
expected response would be an emotional
one. These pictures were presented in
a random order and they're mixed in with
other pictures that have no particular
positive or negative charge. So, you're
looking at some pictures. You're all
wired up so your physiology is being
measured. Occasionally, and you never
know when, a picture will occur that
should evoke, tends to evoke in people a
very strong either positive or negative
emotional response. The thing that the
researchers observed here is that when
the picture was one with a strong
emotional component roughly a half a
second before the picture was shown - and
these are all in random order, they're
not regular, you don't
know when the next picture will come - half a
second before, the physiology of the body
starts to react. These experiments
have now been repeated, I think 20-30
times, using a wide variety of
physiological measurements: heartbeat,
blood volume, brain wave activit
y, electrodermal activity, and even FMRI
measurements of brain activity. So, the
overall results, if you were to combine
all of those studies in a meta-analysis,
which has been done I think back in 2010,
the statistical significance
of those studies is greater than one in
a billion or what we sometimes referred to
as six sigma. So, that's one line of
research. But Daryl Bem, a very important
emeritus psychologist, a professor
of psychology at Cornell University, took
this research a step further.
Dr. Bem incidentally is the co-author of
a major textbook in the field of
psychology, Introduction to Psychology,
[a] widely used textbook for the
introductory classes that are given
typically to freshmen and sophomores in
most colleges, a very respected
psychologist. He thought, well if
physiology is influenced by stimuli from
the future or what we could think of as
backward causality, causality coming to
the present from the future, what about
behavior? He noted that there are a
variety of psychological experiments
where you normally present a stimulus
and then you measure a response. That's
the way it works. In psychology, nobody
thinks to measure the response before
the stimulus is presented, but that's
what he did.
For example, he had a study in which
people are sitting in front of a
computer and on the computer screen they
see two windows with curtains drawn and
they are told behind one of those
windows will be a stimulus. They'll be
told it's a pleasant one or it's an
unpleasant one. They'll be told that.
Then they're asked to choose the window where
that stimulus will be. Now, it’s a binary
test and sometimes the stimulus would be
positive, sometimes it would be negative.
The interesting thing is this, there was
nothing behind the curtains in the
computer because the computer didn't
make a choice until after
the subjects in this experiment had
made their selection. Then, the computer -
using a pure random event generator,
typically quantum mechanically based,
sometimes a pseudo random generator for
different reasons, so they use both -
the computer makes a selection. Lo and
behold, the data shows that people are
precognitively choosing the window
where the positive stimulus appears and
more often than not, precognitively
avoiding the window where the negative
emotionally charged picture would be
shown to them. There were, I
think, nine experiments along these lines.
Some involved memory. For example, it’s
well known, you can understand this
easily, if you rehearse
a list of words and then you're asked to
repeat all the words on this long list,
let's say 50 words, and you rehearse them,
you'll remember them more. Rehearsal
helps memory, well known. Nobody would
dispute that. But what if you don't get
to rehearse the words until after you've
been asked to repeat them? In other words,
a list of, in this case it's 48 words,
is shown to people. Then they’re
asked now, repeat as many of those words
as you can. Then after that’s been done
half of the words are selected at random
by a computer. Then, after the
[music]
repetition has been recorded the person
gets to rehearse those words, the half,
the 50% that have been selected, 24 of the
48 words, they get to rehearse those,
after they’ve already given their
repetition of the initial list. And what
do you know? Yes, the words that get
repeated are the words that were
rehearsed after the event. So, by
rehearsing in the future you can improve
your scores in the present. Can you
believe it? One would say, “Well, I
oughta be able to ace all my exams
that way.” And who knows? I’m
talking about a 2 to 3%
improvement. It's statistically
significant, especially when you're
dealing with a hundred subjects taking
30-40 trials each, so you got 3,000-
4,000 trials in the experiment.
If you're able to show a 3%
Improvement, it's measurable and
statistically significant. In another
study, this is much more complicated, but
here's how it works.
You're shown two pictures. These pictures
are roughly equivalent to each other but
they're different, slightly different.
You're asked, as quickly as you can,
choose which of those you like the best.
Now, in conventional psychology, it is
well understood that you can affect the
person's choice by priming and
what you're affecting is their
reaction time. That is to say, let’s
suppose the two pictures are
really beautiful, but subliminally
before they look at the picture you
flash a word on a screen. They can't even
recognize it consciously,
but subconsciously, apparently, they pick
it up and subliminally, let's say the
word is ugly, well, that creates some
dissonance, the word ugly in beautiful
pictures. So what happens? Reaction time
slows down.
If the word that is shown is
beautiful and the pictures are beautiful,
or ugly and the pictures are ugly,
that's consonance. There isn't any
dissonance and reaction time is not
slowed down. But in Daryl Bem’s research,
the word flashed subliminally, chosen at
random
again, as I recall, is to be either
consonant or dissonant. That word is
shown after they've made their choice.
And yet... so the priming has to take place
by means of reverse causality, which I
can tell you is a topic that is hot in
physics for the last five or six years,
now. There've been annual conferences for
physicists looking at backwards
causality, influences from the future
affecting the present. So, Daryl Bem
conducted nine different experiments
over a period of many years using very
rigorous statistical and methodological
approaches to these studies. After
many years, he published his findings in
the Journal of Personality and Social
Psychology, one of the big journals
published by the American Psychological
Association - not their flagship journal,
but a very important journal. Naturally,
like every parapsychology experiment, it
brought the skeptics out of the woodwork
and it was widely attacked, which
parapsychologists have come to expect.
It's one of the reasons, frankly,
that parapsychologists are such a good
scientist because everything they do is
highly scrutinized and attacked. I
f they're fortunate enough to have a
university position like Daryl Bem, an
emeritus professor, highly esteemed, you
know they're accustomed to it and they
will deal with it appropriately, as he
did. He responded to all of his
criticisms. He made computer software
available so that researchers all over
the world could replicate his studies.
Just a couple of years ago he
published a meta-analysis of 90
different experiments from 33 different
laboratories in 14 different countries.
Once again the statistical results
were comparable to what he had achieved.
If you were to combine those 90
experiments again, you got an overall
statistically significant result. The
odds of getting that result by chance
alone would have been less than one in
ten billion. So, the results were
phenomenal. But unfortunately, to my
understanding, that meta-analysis is
available on the internet. It was at one
time accepted for publication in a
journal, but then a senior editor of that
journal, I think it was called Frontiers,
a major scientific journal,
one of the executive editors
said, “Let's get one more reviewer.”
They didn't like the idea of publishing
a study supporting parapsychology, so
they found a reviewer. That reviewer
said, “No don't publish, because even
though it's statistically significant,
you need to have theoretical
significance. You have to understand how
is it possibly possible for this to
happen.
It defies logic. There's no explanation.”
So, after they'd already accepted
publication, they backed off and they wouldn't
publish this meta-analysis. Of
course it's true,
parapsychologists don't have an accepted
theory for how these things work. There
are many interesting proposals for
theoretical models
and that's very important. But in any case,
you know from the point of
view of a parapsychologist, science
should be data-driven. When you've got 90
replications of a finding it's time to
pay attention. Hopefully, a theoretical
explanation will come along after the
fact. Now, as I mentioned earlier you'll
probably get right away that this data,
these parapsychology studies affect you,
because what it means is that your very
physiology is being influenced by what
is about to happen half a second in the
future. Not only that but your behavior
is affected by events that are
unpredictable to you because they're
random events, but when they occur in the
future, they can actually affect your
behavior.
It raises huge philosophical problems. I'm
sure you could appreciate that, because if
the future is fixed, this is what
physicists call a block universe,
everything is predetermined from the
beginning of time to the end of time, so
we have no free will, which certainly
goes against our common sense
understanding. Now, I know that a huge
amount of human behavior is conditioned,
determined. But I don't think it's all
determined. I think we do have free will.
So, you know that's a puzzle that's going
to take a long time for people to sort
out, but you know the data is there. I
think as a parapsychologist, an
empiricist, a data-driven person, I think
we have to pay attention to the data.
Hopefully, our understanding will follow
from it. I’ll leave you with those
thoughts. Thank you for being with me.
[credits]
